newsitem.title: FRANCE: Strikes hit French air traffic, press, hospitals.
newsitem.headline: Strikes hit French air traffic, press, hospitals.

text.p: Strikes disrupted French air traffic and state hospitals on Thursday, and most newspapers failed to appear as printers joined in the labour unrest.
Cockpit crew unions at British Airways' French units Air Liberte and TAT said they decided to indefinitely extend a strike, begun Wednesday, over pay and working conditions.
The job action, which had been due to end at noon (1000 GMT) on Friday, cut the airlines' flights by half on Thursday.

A spokeswoman for the airlines said TAT, a domestic airline, guaranteed 91 of 180 scheduled flights, and Air Liberte, which flies around the world, would cancel 33 of its 60 flights but would operate all long-haul flights.
The strikers marched in protest to the headquarters of Air Liberte at Paris' Orly airport, blocking the motorway to the terminal for 45 minutes.

Unions, protesting over pay and conditions which they say will be affected by a merger of the two airlines, urged management to negotiate. Marc Rochet, chairman of the two units, has rejected demands for reforms which he said would raise costs by 18 percent.
National newspapers were absent from newsstands while a few regional titles appeared as normal. Some dailies were available on the Internet computer network even if they did not make it onto paper.
The printers' branch of the Communist-led CGT union called the 24-hour strike to protest at cuts in state subsidies to the media, suppression of tax breaks and rising postal charges.
It also demanded retirement at 55 instead of at 60, a move the CGT says will help cut record 12.8 percent unemployment.

Junior hospital doctors kept up a strike, now in its fifth week, although their representatives met aides of Social Affairs Minister Jacques Barrot overnight and both sides said some progress was made on the dispute.
The strikers have called a protest march in Paris on Sunday and a new "health blackout" day, in which they ask other doctors to join them in giving only emergency care, on Monday.
They are protesting against government plans to fine doctors exceeding pre-set spending targets, in order to curb health outlays and plug a gaping welfare deficit.

The doctors' dispute, like demands for early retirement, are testing the conservative government's determination to cut public deficits to qualify for the European Union's planned single currency in 1999.
Bank unions protested at a government decree extending the banks' working hours and called on members to be militant to help them win concessions.

The decree, passed on Wednesday, ditched a 60-year-old rule limiting the banks' working day to eight hours and obliging them to close at weekends. It allows them to be open six days a week, and from 7.30 in the morning to 8.30 at night.
